questions.question: What are some rules for monopolistically competitive graphs in the long run?
options: price exceeds ATC, and ATC intersects marginal revenue at its peak
price is below ATC, and ATC intersects average revenue at its highest point
price equals marginal cost, and ATC intersects average revenue at its lowest point
price = ATC, and ATC intersects marginal cost at its lowest point
questions.explanation: In long-run equilibrium for monopolistic competition, P = ATC (zero economic profit) and the firm produces where MR = MC. ATC intersects MC at the minimum ATC point, though the firm produces less than that output (excess capacity).

questions.question: This sets a product's price based on the product's value to the customer, or on competitive strategy, rather than on the cost of production.
options: variable ticket pricing
market pricing
price discrimination
strategic pricing
questions.explanation: Strategic pricing focuses on perceived value, competitive positioning, or market objectives rather than solely on production costs.

questions.question: What conditions are required to make price discrimination work?
options: must have monopoly power, be able to segregate the market, and consumers can't resell the product
must have government approval, uniform pricing, and consumers can exchange the product
must have limited market power, identical market, and consumers can return the product
there isn't one
questions.explanation: Price discrimination requires: (1) market power, (2) ability to identify and separate consumers by elasticity, and (3) prevention of resale (no arbitrage).

questions.question: What are the two ways in which an oligopolistic firm can react to their competitor's pricing?
options: ignore quantity (inelastic demand) or raise costs (elastic demand)
reduce quantity (inelastic demand) or enhance features (elastic demand)
increase price (elastic demand) or lower quality (inelastic demand)
match price (inelastic demand) or ignore change (elastic demand)
questions.explanation: In the kinked demand curve model, rivals match price cuts (inelastic below kink) but do not match price increases (elastic above kink).

questions.question: What happens in monopolistic competition when new firms enter the market?
options: price rises and demand exceeds ATC
price remains constant and demand falls below ATC
price/quantity falls and demand = ATC = price
quantity increases and supply equals price
questions.explanation: New entry shifts each firm's demand curve left, making it more elastic. In long-run equilibrium, price and quantity per firm fall until P = ATC and economic profit is zero.

scoreMessages.90: Mastery of monopolistic competition long-run rules, strategic pricing, price discrimination conditions, oligopoly reactions, and entry effects.
scoreMessages.70: Solid grasp; review P = ATC in monopolistic competition, price discrimination requirements, and kinked demand curve assumptions.
scoreMessages.50: Needs practice with long-run equilibrium in monopolistic competition, conditions for price discrimination, and firm responses in oligopoly.
scoreMessages.0: Focus on monopolistic competition long-run equilibrium (P = ATC), strategic vs. discriminatory pricing, oligopoly pricing behavior, and effects of market entry.
